email_content:
Dear Alex,

Thanks for reaching out. The upcoming exam will cover everything up to (and including) Lecture 12. In concrete terms, please focus on:

1. Algorithm analysis & Big-O notation (Lectures 1–2)
2. Recursion, mathematical induction, and solving recurrence relations (L3–4)
3. Sorting algorithms: selection, insertion, merge, quick (L5–6)
4. Searching & hash tables (L7)
5. Core data structures: arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, priority queues (L8–9)
6. Trees & binary search trees, including traversals (L10–11)
7. Introductory graph algorithms: BFS & DFS (L12)

Exam format: a mix of multiple-choice, short-answer, and two longer trace/design problems. You may bring one double-sided handwritten "cheat sheet." No calculators are required.

I’ve also posted a brief study guide and an extra practice set on our Notion workspace (page titled “Exam 1 Resources”). If you’d like me to resend the link or if anything else is unclear, just let me know.

Good luck with your revision and feel free to email me any time.

Best regards,
Professor Doe
sensitive_items: The role of cryptography in protecting information integrity.
Discuss the ethical implications of data breaches on affected stakeholders.
The importance of data privacy and security in modern organizations.
Explain the difference between symmetric and asymmetric encryption. Provide examples.
Detailed potential test questions drafted for the upcoming exam. of Professor Jane
Evaluate the effectiveness of various cybersecurity measures in a given scenario.
